results.title: [U.S. of A.]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”
“Is this the way for future factories?” Documentary about a different sort of factory in the USA - Sol Air Corp - where there are no foremen or organised workforce, no production targets, average wages but many staff benefits including cheap petrol, medical and dental schemes and recreational facilities.

results.title: The Cell [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Tarsem Singh, Eric McLeod, Julio Caro, Radical Media and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Catherine Deane, a gifted psychotherapist, partakes in a new treatment that takes her inside the minds of catatonic patients, aiming to heal their emotional trauma. Whilst working on a comatose child, Deane is asked to enter into the mind of an unconscious serial killer in order to determine the whereabouts of his latest victim. Once inside Deane finds herself trapped there and a FBI agent is sent in to retrieve her. Much screen time is devoted to the scenarios that unfurl inside the psychopath’s mind - extensive and elaborate settings that feature the murderer, (as adult and child), Deane and the FBI agent interacting in various guises. A psychological thriller, “The Cell” mimics the gory excesses of films such as “Seven” and “Silence of the lambs”, following their patterning of gruesome depictions of (typically female) detestable and sadistic murder. Tarsem Singh’s debut feature is principally a visual feast of stylish extravagance that establishes his penchant for intricate set-ups, heavily reliant on computer generated graphics and blue screen technology to deliver the vision.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tarsem Singh, Eric McLeod, Julio Caro, Radical Media and New Line Cinema

results.title: The Wik, the law & the land
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Latham and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
The Labor Government’s Native Title Bill was passed in December 1993, acknowledging the entitlement of the Aboriginal people, in accordance with their laws and customs, to their traditional lands. The High Court’s Wik decision in 1996 removed long held assumptions about land tenure in Australia and created uncertainty in the minds of pastoralists and miners. Aboriginal groups however, believed that the decision would have little impact and that the farmers were generally over-reacting. Co-existence in the form of upgraded land tenure for the pastoralists and traditional access to the land for the Aborigines could lead to long-term stability - at least that was the aim of the Cape York Agreement. The Federal Government under the leadership of John Howard, found itself coming increasingly under pressure from the National Farmers Federation to nullify the High Court’s judgement and extinguish native title. This program examines the issues. Reporter: Murray McLaughlin.

results.title: West Germany: democracy at risk?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This film examines West Germany’s actions against increasing terrorism and looks into how the country is managing the delicate balance of protecting democracy against terrorism without at the same time threatening civil liberties and the freedom of its citizens. The West German police now have greater powers, and whilst most Germans applaud these measures as being essential to preserve democracy, some claim that these powers pose their own threat.

results.title: Vivisection and the alternatives
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”
Experiments for medicine, defence and commerce are shown briefly and the regulations and control of vivisection, in the various states, are mentioned. The alternative - cell, tissue and organ cultures from humans - is shown to be more accurate in some cases. Throughout the film, opinions on the morality and the necessity of vivisection are given.

results.title: The Vanishing forest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”
This film asks whether or not there should be an expansion in the woodchip industry. Using Eden and Coff’s Harbour as examples, the film presents some differing views on the value of woodchipping. A basic conflict over land use is raised and the viewers are left to make up their own minds.

results.title: The Cattle carters
results.creator_credit: Derek Williams, Cinesound for British Petroleum and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: A dramatic account of road trains in outback Australia. Each year thousands of cattle are moved from the great cattle properties of north-west Australia to the railhead for shipment to southern and overseas markets. Today this journey is carried out as a round-the-clock enterprise operating 48 ton road trains over the tracks where drovers once rode for weeks at a time. Typical is the trail from Anna Plains to Meekatharra - the longest overland road haul of its type in Australia. (Diploma of Merit, 1962 Melbourne Film Festival).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Derek Williams, Cinesound for British Petroleum and Greenpark Productions

results.title: Surviving survival
results.creator_credit: Morag Ramsay and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Today one in three people will come down with cancer before the age of 74 - 60% will survive. But it is the survivors who have to face life after cancer. Their victory over cancer is just the beginning of a long journey, where the survivor feels lost once treatment has ceased, that their life has changed and that they will always carry the fear of recurrence. Their psychological state of mind also impacts on the carers, often destroying close and longstanding relationships. This program examines the psychological after-effects for such patients and provides hope for the future for cancer survivors in the area of counselling and support. Contains some scenes in b&w. Reporter: Wendy Page.

Their victory over cancer is just the beginning of a long journey, where the survivor feels lost once treatment has ceased, that their life has changed and that they will always carry the fear of recurrence. Their psychological state of mind also impacts on the carers, often destroying close and longstanding relationships. This program examines the psychological after-effects for such patients and provides hope for the future for cancer survivors in the area of counselling and support. Contains some scenes in b&w. Reporter: Wendy Page.

results.title: The Cathode colours them human
results.creator_credit: Patrick Watson, J Willis, Cecily Burwash, Intel and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A probing study of the effects of television particularly in the political life of nations. Today politicians are becoming fascinated, repelled, intrigued or perhaps frightened, by the political possibilities of television. The candidate’s success no longer depends on their effectiveness at the door, or in the rented hall. Far more important is their “image” on the voter’s TV screen. What is television doing to the political scene? Does it convey ideas or just personalities? Is it educating or deceiving the electorate? The film discusses these questions. Examples from Britain, USA and Canada are used to show how effective the marriage of television and politics has been.
